section.title: Technology
section.para: In modern amateur radio, many modes and frequencies are in use. Each mode and each band has it's own characteristics. Net controls and net members both need to be alert to these differences, and use them accordingly.

section.title: Mode Characteristics
section.para: The greatest differences are between modes. Each mode has unique characteristics that the operator must consider.

section.title: CW
section.para: On CW, many stations operate QSK or break-in, and virtually all stations at least operate semi-break-in. This means that the operator can hear the band between elements or at least between words.

On all modes, it generally helps the receiving station to send a few words before beginning the actual message. On CW, it is common practice to precede the message number with NR or HR NR rather than starting right out with the message number. When a station is operating break-in and is comfortable with that, the station may instead start with QSK NR to indicate to the receiver that the sender may be interrupted in the middle of the message to get fills.
When sending a surprising or unusual word, the sender may send a ? character following the word and then repeat the word. This is the equivalent of the phone I say again.

The "official" eight dits as an error indication is rarely used. Most stations send two I's (didit didit) then repeat the mis-sent word. Sometimes when the error should be obvious, the sender simply re-sends the word.
On CW, it is the norm, rather than the exception, to pass traffic off the main net frequency.

section.title: SSB
section.para: SSB is especially challenging because of the poor voice quality and the typically poor band conditions. Unlike CW, the sending station cannot hear the receiving station, so it is imperative that the sender give appropriate breaks to ask for fills, especially when conditions are poor.

On SSB circuits, it is common to spell unusual or unexpected words, or even common words that are easily confused. The proper practice is to give the word, say I spell and then say the word again. For example, "two I spell Tango Whiskey Oscar two". When the word is surprising, but not easily confused with another and the spelling is obvious, the sender will use I say again, for example, "artichoke I say again artichoke".

Because of the difficult conditions often encoutnered on SSB, it is important to use the precise phrase, rather than some made-up phrase. Similarly, it is important to use the proper ICAO phonetics, rather than using some less common phonetic alphabet, or worse still, something invented on the fly.
Like CW, an operator can tell when two stations are transmitting simultaneously, and often can understand both. The transmitting station, however, cannot tell if another station is transmitting.
On phone, the equivalent of the CW HR NR is Please copy number. On SSB especially it is important to use the exact phrasing to reduce misunderstanding.

section.title: FM and AM
section.para: FM detectors exhibit a characteristic known as the "capture effect", meaning that when two stations are transmitting, the listener will only hear the strongest signal. Sometimes when the two signals are close in strength, the listner will hear a hetrodyne, but unlike SSB, only one station, at most, will be intelligible. On AM, multiple stations will cause a heterodyne, but unless their signal strengths are greatly different, neither will be understood.

This effect means that efficiencies possible on SSB are not possible on FM or AM. Stations, especially net controls, should recognize that weaker stations will be totally obscured by stronger stations. On the other hand, some of this disadvantage is offset by the superior audio quality available on FM and AM.

FM detectors take some time to capture the signal, and thus a receiver might miss the first few milliseconds of a transmission. A repeater as a minimum multiplies that effect since the repeater has a receiver too. In addition, many repeaters have short timers before they begin transmissions to eliminate false transmissions resulting from noise. Because of these effects, FM operators in particular should wait a second or so after keying the microphone before speaking. Repeater users should become familiar with their machines as some repeaters may require several seconds of delay.

section.title: Packet
section.para: Packet features "guaranteed" delivery, so many of the adaptations required for other modes are unnecessary on packet. On packet, a user simply logs into a BBS, types S callsign@hamgate.ampr.org and types in the message. Instead of the double dash on CW or Break on phone, sections of the message are separated by a blank line. Messages are separated by two blank lines. It is common practice to end the entire set of messages with a line containing only NNNN. The line /EX notifies the BBS of the end of the transmission.

The message on packet should follow the normal NTS format. To aid the reciever, it is helpful to format the body of the message with five words per line. Messages are typically entered entirely in upper case. As in a normal message, the only punctuation is X.

section.title: Olivia
section.para: The Michigan Digital Traffic Net (MDTN) is working out the proper procedures for handling traffic using Olivia. Olivia offers forward error correction, which while not quite as effective as packet, nonetheless offers a significant improvement over many HF digital modes.

Like FM, neither the transmitting station nor the receiving station can copy multiple stations simulataneously. Olivia, like all digital modes featuring forward error correction, exhibits a significant delay between a character being sent and received. This requires different net procedures that are still in the process of being worked out.
